Voice]] | date=24 July 2011 | accessdate=26 July 2011 | language=Arabic}} In the early morning of 17 February, security forces retook control of the roundabout, killing four protesters and injuring over 300 in the process.{{cite news|title=Clashes Rock Bahraini Capital |date=17 February 2011 |publisher=Al Jazeera |url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2011/02/201121714223324820.html |accessdate=15 April 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5wZPVZfFG?url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/02/201121714223324820.html |archivedate=17 February 2011 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}{{cite news | author=Razaq, Rashid | title = Girl, 2, Shot Dead as Bahrain Police Swoop on Peaceful Protest Camp | url = http://www.thisislondon.co.uk/standard/article-23924314-girl-2-shot-dead-as-bahrain-police-swoop-on-peaceful-protest-camp.do | accessdate=15 April 2011 | work=[[Evening Standard]] |location=London | date=17 February 2011}}{{cite news | author=Box-Turnbull, Greg | title = 5 Killed as Bahrain Cops Fire on Protesters | url = https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/top-stories/2011/02/18/five-killed-as-bahrain-cops-fire-on-protesters-115875-22930655/ | accessdate=15 April 2011 |work=Daily Mirror |location=UK | date=18 February 2011}} Manama was subsequently placed under lockdown, with tanks and armed soldiers taking up positions around the capital city.Staff writer (17 February 2011). [http://www.ynetnews.com/articles/0,7340,L-4030306,00.html "Bahrain Military Locks Down Capital"]. [[Ynetnews]]. Retrieved 19 April 2011. In response, Al Wefaq MPs, then the largest bloc, submitted their resignations from the lower house of the National Assembly of Bahrain.{{rp|75}} The next morning over 50,000 took part in the funerals of victims.Martin Chulov (18 February 2011). [https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/feb/18/bahrain-protests-regime-fall "Bahrain protest: 'The regime must fall, and we will make sure it does'"]. ''The Guardian''. Retrieved 25 July 2012. In the afternoon, hundreds of them marched to Manama. When they neared the Pearl Roundabout, the army opened fire injuring dozens and [[Death of Abdulredha Buhmaid|fatally wounding one]].{{cite web|title=Bahrain: Army, Police Fire on Protesters |publisher=Human Rights Watch |date=18 February 2011 |url=https://www.hrw.org/en/news/2011/02/18/bahrain-army-police-fire-protesters |accessdate=25 July 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/69VBg3kZL?url=http://www.hrw.org/en/news/2011/02/18/bahrain-army-police-fire-protesters |archivedate=28 July 2012 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} Troops withdrew from the Pearl Roundabout on 19 February, and protesters reestablished their camps there.{{cite web| url = http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2011/02/201121914336940622.html | title = Protesters Back in Bahrain Centre|publisher=Al Jazeera| date=20 February 2011 | accessdate=15 April 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110405192740/http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2011/02/201121914336940622.html| archivedate= 5 April 2011 | deadurl= no}}{{cite news| url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12515906 | title = Day of Transformation in Bahrain's 'Sacred Square' |publisher=BBC News | date=19 February 2011 | accessdate=15 April 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110405191822/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12515906| archivedate= 5 April 2011 | deadurl= no}} The crown prince assured protesters that they would be allowed to camp at the roundabout.{{rp|83}} [[File:Hundreds of thousands of Bahrainis taking part in march of loyalty to martyrs.jpg|thumb|Over 100,000 of Bahrainis taking part in the "[[march of loyalty to martyrs]]", honouring political dissidents killed by security forces, on 22 February.]] Subsequent days saw large demonstrations; on 21 February, a pro-government "Gathering of National Unity" drew tens of thousands,{{rp|86}}{{cite news|title=Bangladeshis complain of Bahrain rally 'coercion'|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-south-asia-12773696|publisher=BBC News |date=17 March 2011}} whilst on 22 February the number of protesters at the Pearl Roundabout peaked at over 150,000 after more than 100,000 protesters [[March of loyalty to martyrs|marched]] there.{{rp|88}} On 25 February, a national day of mourning was announced and large anti-government marches were staged.{{cite news | url = https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/25/us-bahrain-protests-idUSTRE71O4VS20110225 | title = Thousands Stage Anti-Government Protest in Bahrain |agency=Reuters| date=25 February 2011 | accessdate=15 April 2011}} Participants were twice as much as those in the 22 February march,Michael Slackman and Nadim Audi (25 February 2011). [https://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/26/world/middleeast/26bahrain.html?_r=1 "Protesters in Bahrain Demand More Changes"]. ''The New York Times''. Retrieved 29 August 2012. estimated at about 40% of Bahraini citizens.[[Stephen Zunes]] (2 March 2011). [http://www.fpif.org/articles/america_blows_it_on_bahrain "America Blows It on Bahrain"]. [[Foreign Policy in Focus]]. Retrieved 12 September 2012. Three days later hundreds protested outside parliament demanding the resignation of all MPs.[http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2011/02/2011228203834331276.html "Protests at Bahrain's parliament"]. Al Jazeera. 28 February 2011. Retrieved 30 August 2012. As protests intensified toward the end of the month,{{cite news| date=23 February 2011 | url = https://www.nytimes.com/imagepages/2011/02/23/world/23bahrain-map.html?ref=middleeast | title = Comparing the Areas of the Protest in ... Pearl Square, Bahrain; Tahrir Square, Egypt |work=The New York Times | accessdate=15 April 2011}} King Hamad was forced to offer concessions in the form of the release of political prisoners{{cite web | url = http://www.alwasatnews.com/3092/news/read/528598/1.html| script-title=ar:"الداخلية": إطلاق سراح 308 أشخاص تنفيذاً للعفو الملكي | الوسط اون لاين – صحيفة الوسط البحرينية – مملكة البحرين | language = Arabic | work=[[Alwasat (Bahraini newspaper)|Alwasat]] | accessdate=15 April 2011}} and the dismissal of three government ministers.{{cite news | author=Richter, Frederick | date=26 February 2011 | url = https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/02/26/us-bahrain-government-idUSTRE71P1A720110226 | title = Shi'ite Dissident Returns to Bahrain from Exile |agency=Reuters | accessdate=15 April 2011}} Protests continued into March, with the opposition expressing dissatisfaction with the government's response.{{cite web|author=Dunlop, W.G. |url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5iwY3NTSpmBl3VTOlFY08tsPi82Rw?docId=CNG.9ffa0c7df5ec323223afd5b1c6a29c99.db1 |title=Thousands Protest in Bahrain as MPs Resign |publisher=[[Agence France-Presse]] (via [[Google News]]) |date=27 February 2011 |accessdate=15 April 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130222031127/https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5iwY3NTSpmBl3VTOlFY08tsPi82Rw?docId=CNG.9ffa0c7df5ec323223afd5b1c6a29c99.db1 |archivedate=22 February 2013 }} A counter-demonstration on 2 March was staged, reportedly the largest political gathering in Bahrain's history in support of the government.[http://www.gulf-daily-news.com/ArchiveNewsDetails.aspx?date=3 March 2011&storyid=300970]. ''[[Gulf Daily News]]''. The next day, two were reportedly injured in clashed between naturalized Sunnis and local Shia youths in [[Hamad Town]],{{rp|117}}[http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2011/03/201134161558262343.html "Anti-government protests in Bahrain"]. Al Jazeera. 4 March 2011. Retrieved 30 August 2012. and police deployed tear gas to break up the clashes.{{cite news | title = New Sectarian Violence Erupts in Bahrain Protests | url = http://www.voanews.com/english/news/middle-east/New-Sectarian-Violence-Erupts-in-Bahrain-Protests-117398278.html | publisher=[[Voice of America|Voice of America News]] | date=4 March 2011 | accessdate=4 March 2011}} Tens of thousands staged two protests the following day, one in Manama and the other headed to [[Bahrain Radio and Television Corporation|state TV]] accusing it of reinforcing sectarian divides.[http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2011/03/201134183528970309.html "Bahrain youth march on state TV"]. Al Jazeera. 4 March 2011. Retrieved 30 August 2012. Protesters escalated their calls for the removal of Prime Minister [[Khalifa bin Salman Al Khalifa]], in power since 1971, from office, gathering outside his office on 6 March.{{cite news|title=Thousands Protest in Bahrain |url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2011/03/20113685530525305.html |publisher=Al Jazeera |date=6 March 2011 |accessdate=15 April 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110412101948/http://english.aljazeera.net//news/middleeast/2011/03/20113685530525305.html |archivedate=12 April 2011 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }} The next day three protests were staged; the first near the US embassy, the second outside the [[Ministry of Interior (Bahrain)|Ministry of Interior]] building and the third and longest in front of [[Bahrain Financial Harbour]].Gregg Carlstrom (7 March 2011). [http://blogs.aljazeera.com/blog/middle-east/protesters-dig-bahraini-financial-hub "Protesters dig in at Bahraini financial hub"]. Al Jazeera. Retrieved 30 August 2012. On 8 March, three hard-line Shia groups called for the abdication of the monarchy and the establishment of a democratic republic via peaceful means, while the larger Al Wefaq group continued demanding an elected government and a [[constitutional monarchy]].{{cite news|author=Noueihed, Lin |title=Hardline Shiite Groups Demand Republic in Bahrain |url=http://www.montrealgazette.com/life/Bahraini+hardline+Shiite+groups+demand+republic/4402091/story.html |publisher=Reuters (via ''[[The Gazette (Montreal)|The Gazette]]'') |date=8 March 2011 |accessdate=15 April 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121011121708/http://www.montrealgazette.com/life/Bahraini%2Bhardline%2BShiite%2Bgroups%2Bdemand%2Brepublic/4402091/story.html |archivedate=11 October 2012 }} On 9 March, thousands protested near Manama's immigration office against naturalizing foreigners and recruiting them in security forces.[http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2011/03/20113917595654981.html "Thousands stage rally in Bahrain"]. Al Jazeera. 9 March 2011. Retrieved 30 August 2012. Hard-liners escalated their moves staging a protest headed to the Royal Court in [[Riffa]] on 11 March. Thousands carrying flowers and flags participated, but were blocked by riot police. During the same day, tens of thousands participated in a march in Manama organized by Al Wefaq.Frederik Richter and Lin Noueihed (11 March 2011). [https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/03/11/us-gulf-protests-bahrain-idUSTRE72A1U320110311 "Bahrain police block march on royal palace"]. Reuters. Retrieved 30 August 2012. The following day, tens of thousands of protesters encircled another royal palace and unlike the previous day, the protest ended peacefully. The same day, U.S. Defense Secretary [[Robert Gates]] was conducting a visit to the country.[https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2011/03/12/AR2011031201563.html "Bahrain protesters march on palace as Gates visits"]. Associated Press (''The Washington Post''). 12 March 2011. Retrieved 30 August 2012. {{webarchive |url=https://www.webcitation.org/6CAYCgqoK?url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2011/03/12/AR2011031201563.html |date=14 November 2012 }} On 13 March, the government reacted strongly, with riot police firing tear gas canisters and tearing down protest tents in the Pearl Roundabout and using tear gas and rubber bullets to disperse demonstrators in the financial district,{{cite news |title= Footage Shows Crackdown in Bahrain|url= http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2011/03/201131375850321229.html |publisher=Al Jazeera| date=13 March 2011 | accessdate=15 April 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110415074449/http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/03/201131375850321229.html| archivedate= 15 April 2011 | deadurl= no}} where they had been camping for over a week.[http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2011/03/201131375850321229.html "Footage shows crackdown in Bahrain"]. Al Jazeera. 13 March 2011. Retrieved 30 August 2012. Witnesses reported that riot police were encircling Pearl Roundabout, the focal point of the protest movement, but the Ministry of Interior said they were aiming to the open the highway and asked protesters to "remain in the [Pearl] roundabout for their safety". Thousands of protesters clashed with police forcing them to retreat.[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12728765 "Bahrain unrest: Manama erupts in violence"]. BBC News. 13 March 2011. Retrieved 30 August 2012. Meanwhile, 150 government supporters stormed the [[University of Bahrain]] where about 5,000 students were staging an anti-government protest.[http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/meast/03/13/bahrain.protests/index.html "Witnesses: King's supporters confront Bahrain students"]. CNN. 13 March 2011. Retrieved 30 August 2012. Clashes occurred between the two groups using sharp objects and stones. Riot police intervened by firing tear gas, rubber bullets and sound bombs on opposition protesters. During the day, the [[General Federation of Workers Trade Unions in Bahrain]] called for a [[general strike]] and the crown prince announced a statement outlining seven principles to be discussed in the political dialogue, including "a parliament with full authority" and "a government that represents the will of the people".{{rp|128–9, 130}} {{multiple image | width1 = 160 | width2 = 180 | width3 = 160 | width4 = 160 | width5 = 160 | width6 = 160 | align = center | footer =
Riot police and protesters clashing violently in Manama on 13 March
| image1 = 2011 Bahraini uprising - March (35).jpg | image2 = Clashes in Bahrain 13 March 2011.jpg | image3 = 2011 Bahraini uprising - March (82).jpg | image4 = 2011 Bahraini uprising - March (98).jpg | image5 = 2011 Bahraini uprising - March (103).jpg | image6 = 2011 Bahraini uprising - March (104).jpg }} As police were overwhelmed by protesters who also blocked roads, the government of Bahrain requested help from neighbouring countries.[http://www.aljazeera.com/indepth/spotlight/bahrain/2011/03/201131454020610721.html "Bahrain 'asks for Gulf help'"]. Al Jazeera. 14 March 2011. Retrieved 30 August 2012. On 14 March, the Gulf Cooperation Council (GCC) agreed to deploy [[Peninsula Shield Force]] troops to Bahrain. [[Saudi Arabia]] deployed about 1,000 troops with armoured support, and the [[United Arab Emirates]] deployed about 500 police officers. The forces crossed into Bahrain via the [[King Fahd Causeway]]. The purported reason of [[Saudi-led intervention in Bahrain|the intervention]] was to secure key installations.{{cite web| url = http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2011/03/2011314124928850647.html | title = Saudi Soldiers Sent into Bahrain|publisher=Al Jazeera| date=15 March 2011 | accessdate=15 April 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110415074458/http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/03/2011314124928850647.html| archivedate= 15 April 2011 | deadurl= no}}{{cite news | url = https://www.nytimes.com/2011/03/15/world/middleeast/15bahrain.html?_r=1&hp | title = Saudi Troops Enter Bahrain to Help Put Down Unrest |work=The New York Times |date=14 March 2011 | accessdate=14 March 2011 | first1=Ethan | last1=Bronner | first2=Michael | last2=Slackman| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110317034801/http://www.nytimes.com/2011/03/15/world/middleeast/15bahrain.html?_r=1&hp| archivedate=17 March 2011| deadurl= no}} According to the BBC, "The Saudis took up positions at key installations but never intervened directly in policing the demonstrators", though warned that they would deal with the protesters if Bahrain did not.{{cite news |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-16052343 |title=Saudi crackdown takes on sectarian character |author=Bill Law |date=14 December 2011 |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=23 January 2012}} [[Saudi-led intervention in Bahrain|The intervention]] marked the first time an Arab government requested foreign help during the Arab Spring. The opposition reacted strongly, calling it an occupation and a declaration of war, and pleaded for international help.{{cite news | title = Gulf States Send Force to Bahrain Following Protests | url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12729786 |publisher=BBC News | date=14 March 2011 | accessdate=15 April 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110420040119/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12729786| archivedate= 20 April 2011 | deadurl= no}} === State of Emergency === [[File:2011 Bahraini uprising - March (152).jpg|thumb|Thousands of protesters denouncing the [[Saudi-led intervention in Bahrain|Saudi intervention]] in a march to the Saudi embassy in Manama on 15 March]] On 15 March, King Hamad declared a three-month state of emergency. Thousands of protesters marched to the Saudi embassy in Manama denouncing the GCC intervention, while clashes between security officers using shotgun and demonstrators took place in various locations. The most violent were on Sitra island stretching throughout morning till afternoon resulting in two deaths and over 200 injuries among protesters and one death among police.{{rp|140}}{{cite news| title = Two Killed in Bahrain Violence Despite Martial Law |publisher=BBC News | url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12751464 | date=15 March 2011 | accessdate=15 April 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110405202839/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-12751464| archivedate= 5 April 2011 | deadurl= no}} Doctors at the [[Salmaniya Medical Complex]] said it was overwhelmed with injured and that some had bullet wounds. [[Jeffrey D. Feltman]], then the US [[Assistant Secretary of State for Near Eastern Affairs]] was sent to Bahrain to mediate between the two sides. Opposition parties said they accepted the US initiative while the government did not respond.{{rp|142–3}} ;16 March Crackdown In the early morning of 16 March, over 5,000 security forces backed by tanks and helicopters stormed the Pearl Roundabout, where protesters had camped for about a month.{{rp|143}} The number of protesters was much lower than that in previous days due to many of them returning to villages to protect their homes.Michael Birnbaum and Joby Warrick (17 March 2011). [https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2011/03/16/AR2011031603775_3.html "Bahrain arrests opposition leaders as crackdown intensifies"]. ''The Washington Post''. Retrieved 30 August 2012. Intimidated by the amount of security forces, most protesters retreated from the location, while others decided to stay and were violently cleared within two hours.{{cite web | date=16 March 2011 | url = http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/03/201131643831976772.html | title = Curfew Follows Deadly Bahrain Crackdown|publisher=Al Jazeera | accessdate=16 April 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110414183819/http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/03/201131643831976772.html| archivedate= 14 April 2011 | deadurl= no}} Then, security forces cleared road blockades and the financial harbor, and moved to take control over Salmaniya hospital. They entered the hospital building with their sticks, shields, handguns and assault rifles after clearing the parking area,{{rp|144–5}} and treated it as a crime scene.{{rp|31:50}} Witnesses said ambulances were captured inside the hospital and some health workers were beaten. Unable to reach Salmaniya hospital, the wounded were taken to small clinics outside the capital, which were stormed by police soon after, prompting protesters to use mosques as field clinics. Then, the army moved to opposition strongholds where it set up a number of checkpoints and thousands of riot police entered, forcing people to retreat to their homes by nightfall.{{cite video |people=May Ying Welsh and Tuki Laumea |year=2011 |title=Bahrain: Shouting in the Dark |url=http://www.aljazeera.com/programmes/2011/08/201184144547798162.html|publisher=Al Jazeera|location=Bahrain |accessdate=29 July 2012}}{{rp|32–5}} The Al Wefaq party advised people to stay off the streets, avoid confrontations with security forces and stay peaceful after the army had announced a nighttime 12-hour curfew in Manama and banned all sorts of public gatherings. Eight people had died that day, five by gunshot, one by birdshot and two police reportedly run over by an SUV.{{rp|144, 146–7}} {{multiple image | width1 = 160 | width2 = 180 | width3 = 160 | width4 = 160 | width5 = 160 | width6 = 160 | align = center | footer =
Riot police and army forces supported by armoured vehicles and a military helicopter storm Pearl Roundabout on 16 March
| image1 = 2011 Bahraini uprising - March (180).jpg | image2 = Riot police fire tear gas 16 March.jpg | image3 = 2011 Bahraini uprising - March (195).jpg | image4 = 2011 Bahraini uprising - March (268).jpg | image5 = 2011 Bahraini uprising - March (6).jpg | image6 = 2011 Bahraini uprising - March (214).jpg }} ;Arrests and Widening Crackdown By the early hours of 17 March, over 1,000 protesters had been arrested,{{rp|34:50}} including [[Bahrain Thirteen|seven leading opposition figures]], among them [[Abduljalil al-Singace]], [[Abdulwahab Hussain]], [[Ibrahim Sharif]] and [[Hasan Mushaima]].[https://www.hrw.org/en/news/2011/03/18/bahrain-protest-leaders-arbitrarily-detained "Bahrain: Protest Leaders Arbitrarily Detained"]. Human Rights Watch. 18 March 2011. Retrieved 25 August 2012. In an interview with Al Jazeera before his arrest, the latter had claimed protesters were gunned down despite offering only non-violent civil resistance.{{cite news| title = Arrests Follow Deadly Bahrain Crackdown|publisher=Al Jazeera | url = http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/03/201131733318735470.html | date=17 March 2011 | accessdate=16 April 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110405191837/http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/03/201131733318735470.html| archivedate= 5 April 2011 | deadurl= no}}{{cite web|date=17 March 2011 |url=http://blogs.aljazeera.net/live/middle-east/live-blog-bahrain-crackdown |title=Live Blog: Bahrain Crackdown |publisher=Al Jazeera |accessdate=16 April 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110319111856/http://blogs.aljazeera.net/live/middle-east/live-blog-bahrain-crackdown |archivedate=19 March 2011 }} In response to the government's reaction to the protests, a number of top Shia officials submitted their resignations, including two ministers, four appointed MPs and a dozen judges.[[Ethan Bronner]] (17 March 2011). [https://www.nytimes.com/2011/03/18/world/middleeast/18bahrain.html?_r=1 "Opposition Leaders Arrested in Bahrain as Crackdown Grows"]. ''The New York Times''. Retrieved 30 August 2012.Habib Toumi (17 March 2011). [http://gulfnews.com/news/gulf/bahrain/some-top-officials-have-quit-reports-say-1.778292 "Some top officials have quit, reports say"]. ''Gulf News''. Retrieved 30 August 2012. Protesters in several villages ignored the curfew and gathered in streets only to be dispersed by security forces,{{rp|149}} which allowed funerals as the only means of public gathering.{{rp|45}} Arrested protesters were taken to police stations where they were mistreated and verbally abused.{{rp|151}} Later in the day, surgeon Ali al-Ekri was arrested from the still surrounded Salmaniya hospital and by April another 47 health workers had been arrested.{{rp|43}} Their [[Bahrain health worker trials|case]] drew wide international attention.{{cite web |url=http://www.thelancet.com/journals/lancet/article/PIIS0140-6736(11)61562-6/fulltext |title=Medical community urged to defend Bahraini doctors |author=Sharmila Devi |date=8 October 2011 |work=The Lancet |accessdate=24 May 2012}} Patients at the hospital reported getting beaten and verbally abused by security forces and staff said patients with protest related injuries were kept in wards 62 and 63 where they were held as captives, denied health care and beaten on daily basis to secure confessions.{{rp|35–6, 42}} [[Physicians for Human Rights]] accused the government of violating medical neutrality{{cite news| url=https://www.independent.co.uk/opinion/commentators/richard-sollom-the-shocking-thing-is-that-bahrain-abuse-is-systematic-2270678.html |location=London |work=The Independent | title=Richard Sollom: The shocking thing is that Bahrain abuse is systematic | date=21 April 2011}} and [[Médecins Sans Frontières]] said injured protesters were denied medical care and that hospitals were used as baits to snare them. The government of Bahrain dismissed these reports as lacking any evidenceStaff writer (7 April 2011). [https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5jEbzfg0NYmpGm2PsexchJJ3wlMuQ?docId=CNG.6f1a3c295003e2f3af5b879590880652.281 "Bahrain Hospitals Used as 'Bait' in Crackdown: MSF"]. [[Agence France-Presse]] (via [[Google News]]). Retrieved 15 April 2011. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130222031122/https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5jEbzfg0NYmpGm2PsexchJJ3wlMuQ?docId=CNG.6f1a3c295003e2f3af5b879590880652.281 |date=22 February 2013 }} and said forces were only deployed in the hospital to keep order.[http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2011/04/20114781638439583.html "Bahrain hospitals 'paralysed' by unrest"]. Al Jazeera. 7 April 2011. Retrieved 3 September 2012. [[File:Pearl Monument Leveled.jpg|thumb|A cement column falling on a construction vehicle killing its driver during demolition process of Pearl Roundabout on 18 March]] On 18 March, the Pearl Monument in the middle of the Pearl Roundabout was demolished on government orders{{cite news| date=19 March 2011 | url = http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/meast/03/18/bahrain.protests/?hpt=T2 | title = U.S. Condemns Arrest of Opposition Figures in Bahrain | publisher=CNN | accessdate=16 April 2011}} and a worker died in process.{{rp|47}} The government said the demolition was in order to erase "bad memories"[http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2011/03/201131823554586194.html "Bahrain tears down protest symbol"]. Al Jazeera. 18 March 2011. She was subsequently released following international pressure.{{rp|38–42, 50}} ==Aftermath== {{main|Aftermath of the Bahraini uprising of 2011}} [[File:Sheikh Mohammed al-Barbaghi Mosque being demolished.jpg|thumb|A loader destroying the 400-year-old Amir Mohammed Braighi mosque in [[A'ali]]]] In April, as a part of the crackdown campaign, the government moved to destroy Shia places of worship, demolishing thirty five mosques. Although many had been standing for decades, the government said they were illegally built,{{rp|45}} and justified destroying some of them at night as to avoid hurting people's psychology. Among the destroyed was the Amir Mohammed Braighi mosque in [[A'ali]] which was built more than 400 years ago. On 2 April, following an episode on Bahrain TV alleging it had published false and fabricated news, ''[[Al-Wasat (Bahraini newspaper)|Al-Wasat]]'', a local newspaper was banned briefly and its editor [[Mansoor Al-Jamri]] replaced.{{rp|390}}[http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2011/04/2011438401186997.html "Bahrain bans main opposition newspaper"]. The main reasons for dismissals were absence during the one-week general strike, taking part in protests and public display of anti-government opinion.{{rp|331}} Although the government and several companies said the strike was illegal, the Bahrain Independent Commission of Inquiry stated it was "within... the law".{{rp|353}} Some workers who underwent investigations said they were shown images associating them with protests.{{rp|334}} Head of the Civil Service Bureau initially denied those reports, but few months later acknowledged that several hundred have been dismissed.{{rp|335}} In total 2,464 private sector and 2,075 public sector employees were fired for a total of 4539.{{rp|341–54}} ;May On 2 May, authorities arrested two of Al Wefaq's resigned MPs, [[Matar Matar]] and [[Jawad Ferooz]].[http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2011/05/201152205239385476.html "Bahrain arrests opposition politicians"]. VOA News. 6 July 2011. Retrieved 10 July 2011. Human Rights Watch said opposition parties were marginalized in the dialogue as they were only given 15 seats out of 297 despite winning 55% of votes in [[Bahraini parliamentary election, 2010|2010 election]].{{cite news|title=Bahrain's Human Rights Crisis|url=https://www.hrw.org/news/2011/07/05/bahrains-human-rights-crisis|publisher=[[Human Rights Watch]]|date=5 July 2011}} ===2011=== On 1 June, protests erupted across Shia-dominated areas of Bahrain to demand the end of martial law as the state of emergency was officially lifted.{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/jun/01/bahrain-protests-martial-law |location=London |work=The Guardian | first=Martin | last=Chulov | title=Bahrain sees new clashes as martial law lifted | date=1 June 2011}} Protests continued through early June, with demonstrators marching around the destroyed Pearl Roundabout, but security forces battled back and regularly dispersed demonstrators.{{cite news|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/06/201163135520207409.html|publisher=Al Jazeera|date=3 June 2011|accessdate=4 June 2011|title=Bahrain police 'suppress protest'}} The [[2011 Bahrain Grand Prix|2011 edition]] of the [[Bahrain Grand Prix]], a major Formula One racing event, was officially cancelled as the uprising wore on.[http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/babylonbeyond/2011/06/bahrain-formula-1-boss-says-grand-prix-postponed.html?dlvrit=99665 BAHRAIN: Formula 1 boss says Grand Prix canceled] -''Los Angeles Times''. On 11 June, protest was announced in advance but did not receive government permission, opposition supporters said. It was held in the Shi'ite district of [[Sar, Bahrain|Saar]], west of the capital. Police did not stop up to 10,000 people who came to the rally, many in cars, said a [[Reuters]] witness. Helicopters buzzed overhead.[https://www.reuters.com/article/2011/06/11/us-bahrain-idUSTRE75A19G20110611 Thousands of Bahrainis attended a rally for political reform on Saturday in the Gulf Arab state that crushed a pro-democracy protest movement in March.] ''-Reuters''. {{webarchive |url=https://www.webcitation.org/6B8ljEYJm?url=http://www.reuters.com/article/2011/06/11/us-bahrain-idUSTRE75A19G20110611 |date=3 October 2012 }} On 13 June, Bahrain's rulers commenced the trials of 48 medical professionals, including some of the country's top surgeons, a move seen as the hounding of those who treated injured protesters during the popular uprising which was crushed by the military intervention of Saudi Arabia.{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/video/middleeast/2011/06/201161373514815872.html |title=Bahrain medics on trial over protests|publisher=Al Jazeera |accessdate=14 June 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110613121136/http://english.aljazeera.net/video/middleeast/2011/06/201161373514815872.html| archivedate= 13 June 2011 | deadurl= no}} On 18 June, The Bahraini government decided to lift a ban on the largest opposition party.[http://lincolntribune.com/?p=14392 "Bahrain to lift ban on opposition party"]. The Lincoln Tribune. 18 June 2011. Retrieved 24 June 2011. On 22 June, the Bahraini government sent 21 opposition figures to be tried by a special security court{{cite news|author=Bill Law |url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-13872206 |title=Bahrain unrest: Eight Shia activists sentenced to life |publisher=BBC |date=17 June 2011 |accessdate=23 June 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110623015351/http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-13872206| archivedate= 23 June 2011 | deadurl= no}} which sentenced 8 pro-democracy activists to life in prison for their role in the uprising.{{cite news|first=Martin |last=Chulov |url=https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/jun/22/bahraini-activists-jailed-life |title=Bahrain rights activists jailed for life | World news |work=The Guardian |location=UK |accessdate=22 June 2011 |date=22 June 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110622113441/http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/jun/22/bahraini-activists-jailed-life| archivedate= 22 June 2011 | deadurl= no}} Other defendants were sentenced to between two and fifteen years in jail.{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/06/20116228219100399.html |title=Life sentences for Bahrain activists|publisher=Al Jazeera |accessdate=22 June 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110622115028/http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/06/20116228219100399.html| archivedate= 22 June 2011 | deadurl= no}} On 9 August, the Bahrain Independent Commission of Inquiry announced that 137 detainees had been released, including Matar Matar and Jawad Fayrouz, Shia MPs from the Al-Wefaq opposition party.[http://www.france24.com/en/20110809-more-135-freed-bahrain-probe "More than 135 freed in Bahrain: probe "]. AFP. 9 August 2011. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110810091812/http://www.france24.com/en/20110809-more-135-freed-bahrain-probe |date=10 August 2011 }} === 2012 === [[File:Bahrain map.png|thumb|Map of Bahrain]] [[File:March of 9 March by Korah 5.jpg|thumb|At least 100,000 people participated in one of the largest anti-government protests along [[Budaiya]] highway on 9 March]] According to the ''Gulf Daily News'' on 1 February 2012, King Hamad's media affairs adviser Nabeel Al Hamer revealed plans for new talks between the opposition and the government on his Twitter account. He said that talks with political societies "had already begun to pave the way clear for a dialogue that would lead to a united Bahrain". The move was supported by Al Wefaq National Islamic Society former MP [[Abduljalil Khalil]], who said that the society was "ready for serious dialogue and this time had no preconditions". He reiterated that "People want serious reforms that reflect their will and what they really want for their future." However the National Unity Assembly board member Khalid Al Qoud said that his society would not participate in talks "until those behind the acts of violence were arrested".{{cite news|author=Rebecca Torr|title=Second dialogue chance for unity|date= 1 February 2012|publisher=Gulf Daily news|url =http://www.gulf-daily-news.com/NewsDetails.aspx?storyid=322833|accessdate=2 February 2012}} The call for dialogue was echoed by Crown Prince [[Salman bin Hamad bin Isa Al Khalifa]], who backed the initiative.{{cite news|title=Ray of hope amid statements about national solution|date=31 January 2012|work=Gulf News|url= http://gulfnews.com/news/gulf/bahrain/ray-of-hope-amid-statements-about-national-solution-1.973923|accessdate=2 February 2012}} The Bahrain Debate is an initiative organised "by the youth for the youth" that brings together young people from across the spectrum of Bahraini society to debate the political and social problems confronting the country, and their solutions. The debate is not funded or organised by any political group. "In light of what has happened in Bahrain, people need to express themselves in a constructive way and listen to others' views," said Ehsan Al Kooheji, one of the organisers. "The youth are the country's future because they have the power to change things. They are extremely dynamic and energetic but have felt that they don't have a platform to express their opinions."[http://bahraindebate.com/ Bahrain Debate 2012] Bahraini independents worried that the island will slide into sectarian violence also began an effort to break the political stalemate between pro-government and opposition forces. Dr. [[Ali Fakhro]], a former minister and ambassador "respected across the political spectrum", told Reuters that he hoped to get moderates from both sides together at a time when extremists are making themselves felt throughout the Gulf Arab state. Fakhro said the initiative, launched at a meeting on 28 January 2012, involved persuading opposition parties and pro-government groups meeting outside a government forum and agreeing on a list of basic demands for democratic reform. He launched the plan at a meeting of prominent Bahrainis with no official political affiliations or memberships, called the National Bahraini Meeting. A basic framework for discussion is the seven points for democratic reform announced by Crown Prince Salman in March 2011.{{cite news|agency=Reuters|title = Worried Bahrainis seek talks as clashes worsen|date=2 February 2012| publisher=Arabain Business|url=http://www.arabianbusiness.com/worried-bahrainis-seek-talks-as-clashes-worsen-443277.html |accessdate=2 February 2012}} Bahraini newspaper ''[[Al Ayam (Bahrain)|Al Ayam]]'' reported on 7 March 2012 that the government and the opposition political societies were approaching an agreement to start a dialogue towards reconciliation and reunifying the country.{{cite news|title =الإعلان عن حوار لمّ الشمل خلال أيام|date=7 March 2012|publisher=Alayam|url =http://www.alayam.com/newsdetails.aspx?id=52463}} On 9 March 2012, hundreds of thousands protested in one of the biggest anti-government rallies to date. According to [[CNN]], the march "filled a four-lane highway between [[Diraz]] and Muksha".{{cite news |publisher=CNN|title = Renewed protests demand democracy in Bahrain | date=9 March 2012 | url = http://edition.cnn.com/2012/03/09/world/meast/bahrain-protests/ | accessdate=10 March 2012}} A Reuters photographer estimated the number to be over 100,000 while opposition activists estimated the number to be between 100,000 and 250,000.{{cite news| title = Hundreds of thousands protest for democracy in Bahrain | date=9 March 2012 | publisher=[[Al Akhbar (Lebanon)|Al Akhbar]] | url = http://english.al-akhbar.com/content/hundreds-thousands-protest-democracy-bahrain | accessdate=11 March 2012}} Nabeel Rajab, president of the Bahrain Centre for Human Rights called the march "the biggest in our history". The march was called for by Sheikh Isa Qassim, Bahrain's top Shia cleric. Protesters called for the downfall of the King and the release of imprisoned political leaders. The protest ended peacefully, however hundreds of youths tried to march back to the site of the now demolished symbolic Pearl roundabout, and were dispersed by security forces with tear gas.{{cite news | author=Simeon Kerr | title = Bahrain protesters march in huge rally | date=9 March 2012 |work=Financial Times | url = http://www.ft.com/intl/cms/s/0/dd416cdc-69ff-11e1-a26e-00144feabdc0.html#axzz1ofXPlmwk | accessdate=10 March 2012}} On 10 April, seven policemen were injured when a homemade [[Eker bombing (2012)|bomb exploded]] in [[Eker]], the Ministry of the Interior said. The ministry blamed protesters for the attack.[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-17663642 "Bahrain police injured in bomb attack"]. BBC. 10 April 2012. Retrieved 9 June 2012. This was followed on 19 October by the [[siege of Eker]]. On 18 April, in the run-up to the scheduled [[2012 Bahrain Grand Prix]], a car used by [[Force India]] mechanics had been involved in a petrol bombing,{{cite news|title=@f1elvis – 18 April|url=https://twitter.com/f1elvis/status/192701572298452993|first=Marc|last=Priestley|work=@f1elvis|publisher=Twitter|date=18 April 2012|accessdate=18 April 2012}} though there were no injuries or damage.{{cite news|title=@f1elvis – 18 April|url=https://twitter.com/f1elvis/status/192725462814957568|first=Marc|last=Priestley|work=@f1elvis|publisher=Twitter|date=18 April 2012|accessdate=18 April 2012}} The team members had been travelling in an unmarked car{{cite news|title=@adamcooperf1 – 19 April|url=https://twitter.com/adamcooperf1/status/192877576744730624|first=Adam|last=Cooper|work=@adamcooperf1|publisher=Twitter|date=19 April 2012|accessdate=19 April 2012}} and were held up by an impromptu [[roadblock]] which they were unable to clear before a petrol bomb exploded nearby.{{cite news|title=@adamcooperf1 – 19 April|url=https://twitter.com/adamcooperF1/statuses/192876895044517888|first=Adam|last=Cooper|work=@adamcooperf1|publisher=Twitter|date=19 April 2012|accessdate=19 April 2012}} [[2012 Bahrain Grand Prix protests|Protests and protesters]] sharply increased in the spotlight of international press for the Grand Prix, and to condemn the implicit endorsement of the government by Formula One.{{cite news|url=http://www.foxnews.com/world/2012/04/20/bahrain-tightens-security-ahead-f1-weekend675931/ |title=Bahrain protesters swell ahead of F1 weekend |publisher=Fox News Channel |date=20 April 2012}}{{cite news| url=http://rendezvous.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/04/20/the-unforeseen-consequences-of-the-bahrain-grand-prix/|work=The New York Times|first=Brad|last=Spurgeon|title=The Unforeseen Consequences of the Bahrain Grand Prix|date=20 April 2012}} On 30 October 2012, the government banned all protests, threatening legal action against anyone who attempted to organize a rally or demonstration. It was unclear how the ban would change the government's handling of protests, as many were already considered illegal and met with force.Tim Phillips, [http://activistdefense.wordpress.com/2012/11/20/white-house-continues-to-support-brutally-repressive-regime-in-bahrain/ "White House Continues to Support Brutally Repressive Regime in Bahrain"], Activist Defense, 20 November 2012. ===2013=== Inspired by the Egyptian [[Tamarod|Tamarod Movement]] that played a role in the [[2013 Egyptian coup d'état|removal]] of President [[Mohamed Morsi]], Bahraini opposition activists called for mass protests starting on 14 August, the forty second anniversary of [[Bahrain Independence Day]] under the banner [[Bahrain Tamarod]]. The day also marked the two and half anniversary of the Bahraini uprising.{{cite web|title=Is Bahrain Next?|publisher=[[Al Monitor]]|language=English, translated by Sahar Ghoussoub from the original Arabic article in ''[[As-Safir]]''|url=http://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/politics/2013/07/bahrain-opposition-tamarrud-protests-august-14.html|date=5 July 2013|accessdate=10 August 2013}} In response, the [[Ministry of Interior (Bahrain)|Ministry of Interior (MoI)]] warned against joining what it called "illegal demonstrations and activities that endanger security" and stepped up security measures.{{cite news|title=Opposition slams Bahrain warning on Egypt-inspired demos |url=https://www.google.com/hostednews/afp/article/ALeqM5jbZDd9di6Nw6w6ZrgMMbu83N-xYg?docId=CNG.019754b778134f8f84efbc7f5424d121.4a1 |publisher=[[Google]] |agency=AFP |date=14 July 2013 |accessdate=10 August 2013 }}{{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}{{cite news|title=Bahrain steps up security ahead of rebellion movement call|work=[[The Philippine Star]]|agency=[[Xinhua News Agency]]|date=14 July 2013|accessdate=10 August 2013|url=http://www.philstar.com/world/2013/07/14/968881/bahrain-steps-security-ahead-rebellion-movement-call}} According to a report by a Bahraini human rights body, the country saw 745 protests in just December alone. The government's reaction to dissent included arrests of 31 children, home raids and enforced disappearances. Out of the 745 "sporadic protests", more than a half were suppressed by security forces, according to a report by the Liberties and Human Rights Department in [[Al Wefaq National Islamic Society]]. ===2014=== On 3 March, a bomb blast by Shia protesters in the village of [[Al Daih]] killed 3 police officers. One of the police officers killed was an Emirati policeman from the [[Peninsula Shield Force]]. The two other officers killed were Bahraini policemen. 25 suspects were arrested in connection to the bombing. In response to the violence, the Cabinet of Bahrain designated various protest groups as terrorist organizations.{{cite news|title=Bahrain arrests 25 after death of 3 policemen in bomb attack|url=http://www.bahrainnews.net/index.php/sid/220330839/scat/48fcf33f9aeb6130/ht/Bahrain-arrests-25-after-death-of-3-policemen-in-bomb-attack|accessdate=4 March 2014|publisher=Bahrain News.Net}} In November, the first parliamentary elections were held in Bahrain since the beginning of the protests despite boycotts held by the Shia-majority opposition.https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-30151786 ===Afterwards=== ====2017==== On 15 January 2017, the [[Cabinet of Bahrain]] passed a [[capital punishment]] sentence of [[execution by firing squad]] on three men found guilty for the bomb attack in 2014 that killed three security forces.{{cite news |title=Bahrain executes three, despite protests |url=http://www.dw.com/en/bahrain-executes-three-despite-protests/a-37137212 |work=DW.COM |agency=[[Deutsche Welle]] |date=15 January 2017 |accessdate=15 January 2017}} ==Censorship and repression== {{further|Internet in Bahrain}} The Bahrain Centre for Human Rights said that Bahraini authorities were blocking a ''Facebook'' group being used for planned protests on 14 February, and that its own website had been blocked for many years.{{cite press release|title=In Fear of Transmitting the Tunisian and Egyptian Demonstrations to Bahrain: Blocking a Facebook Group That Calls People To Go Down the Streets and Demonstrate Against the Authority's Policy |publisher=[[Bahrain Centre for Human Rights]] |date=6 February 2011 |url=http://bahrainrights.org/en/node/3721 |accessdate=16 April 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5wNUbTPmx?url=http://bahrainrights.org/en/node/3721 |archivedate=9 February 2011 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}{{cite news|author1=Zavis, Alexandra |author2=Daragahi, Borzou |title=Bahrain: Authorities Crack Down on Dissent on the Web, Rights Group Says |date=6 February 2011 |work=Babylon and Beyond'' (blog of [[Los Angeles Times]]'') |url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/babylonbeyond/2011/02/bahrain-authorities-crack-down-on-dissent-on-the-web.html |accessdate=16 April 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5wNOYpXJs?url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/babylonbeyond/2011/02/bahrain-authorities-crack-down-on-dissent-on-the-web.html |archivedate=9 February 2011 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }} Nabeel Rajab, head of the centre, said that the group was "only asking for political reforms, right of political participation, respect for human rights, stopping of systematic discrimination against Shias". Several bloggers were arrested prior to 6 February. Following the deployment of Gulf Cooperation Council forces, the government stepped up the arrests of Shia Muslims, including many cyber activists, with more than 300 detained and dozens missing, the opposition stated on 31 March. Rajab said that a growing number of reform campaigners were going into hiding, after the country's most-prominent blogger, Mahmood al-Yousif, was arrested a day earlier, on 30 March.{{cite news| title = Bahrain Steps Up Crackdown on Opposition| url = http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/03/2011331131744583927.html |publisher=Al Jazeera | date=31 March 2011 | accessdate=16 April 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110405191859/http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/03/2011331131744583927.html| archivedate= 5 April 2011 | deadurl= no}} Although al-Yousif was released on 1 April, several other people, including Abdul Khaleq al-Oraibi, a pro-opposition doctor working at Salmaniya Hospital, were detained.{{cite news | author=Solomon, Erika | title=Bahrain Steps Up Detentions, Releases Prominent Blogger | url=http://www.trust.org/alertnet/news/bahrain-steps-up-detentions-releases-prominent-blogger/ | publisher=Reuters (via [[AlertNet]]) | date=1 April 2011 | accessdate=16 April 2011 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120406115714/http://www.trust.org/alertnet/news/bahrain-steps-up-detentions-releases-prominent-blogger/ | archivedate=6 April 2012 | df=dmy-all }} ''[[Google Earth]]'' had previously been blocked after it showed the locations of the ruling family's estates which was reported to have stirred up discontent.{{cite web | author=Lubin, Gus | url = http://www.businessinsider.com/bahrain-google-earth-2011-3# | title = These Are the Controversial Satellite Photos That Set Off Protests in Bahrain | publisher=[[Business Insider]] | date=2 March 2011 | accessdate=16 April 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110513210146/http://www.businessinsider.com/bahrain-google-earth-2011-3| archivedate= 13 May 2011 | deadurl= no}} On 3 April, Bahraini authorities prevented the publishing of ''Al-Wasat'', the country's main opposition newspaper, and blocked its website. The [[Information Affairs Authority]] was said to be investigating allegations that editors intentionally published misleading information.{{cite news| title = Bahrain Bans Main Opposition Newspaper| url = http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/04/2011438401186997.html |publisher=Al Jazeera | date=3 April 2011 | accessdate=16 April 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110405190124/http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/04/2011438401186997.html| archivedate= 5 April 2011 | deadurl= no}}{{registration required|date=April 2011}} {{cite news | title = Bahrain Closes Only Independent Paper |work=Financial Times | url = http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/6b5999de-5de7-11e0-b1d8-00144feab49a.html#ixzz1IU9xsIht | date=3 April 2011 |accessdate=3 April 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110407233429/http://www.ft.com/cms/s/0/6b5999de-5de7-11e0-b1d8-00144feab49a.html| archivedate=7 April 2011| deadurl= no}} However, on 4 April, the newspaper resumed printing, although a government spokesperson said the newspaper had broken press laws.{{cite news|title=Bahrain Workers Fired for Supporting Protests |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/04/2011460205145476.html |publisher=Al Jazeera |date=6 April 2011 |accessdate=16 April 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110410202235/http://english.aljazeera.net//news/middleeast/2011/04/2011460205145476.html |archivedate=10 April 2011 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }} On 14 April, the Justice Ministry stated it was seeking to ban the Wefaq party, as well as the Islamic Action Party, a Wefaq ally, for "undertaking activities that harmed social peace, national unity, and inciting disrespect for constitutional institutions."{{cite news|title=Bahrain Moves To Ban Main Opposition Party |url=http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/04/2011414145159153258.html |publisher=Al Jazeera |date=14 April 2011 |accessdate=16 April 2011 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110415074106/http://english.aljazeera.net//news/middleeast/2011/04/2011414145159153258.html |archivedate=15 April 2011 |deadurl=yes |df=dmy }} The US State Department quickly raised concerns about these plans, prompting the Bahraini authorities to state, a day later, that they were holding off on any action until investigations into the Wefaq party were finalized.{{cite news | title = Bahrain Backs Off on Opposition Party Ban| url = http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/04/201141573222422175.html |publisher=Al Jazeera | date=15 April 2011 | accessdate=16 April 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110415103419/http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/04/201141573222422175.html| archivedate= 15 April 2011 | deadurl= no}} In early May, Al Wefaq claimed that in response to the protests, Bahraini police had "raided up to 15 mainly girls schools, detaining, beating and threatening to rape girls as young as 12." Based on its own investigation, [[Al Jazeera English]] described the police actions as "periodic raids on girls' schools" and interviewed a 16-year-old girl, "Heba", who had been taken from her school together with three other pupils and beaten severely during three days of police detention. By mid-May, 28 mosques and Shia religious buildings had been destroyed by the Bahraini authorities in response to the anti-government protests, according to ''Al Jazeera English'' and journalist [[Robert Fisk]]. The Justice Ministry stated that the mosques were destroyed because they were unlicensed. [[Adel Mouwda]], first deputy speaker of the Council of Representatives of Bahrain, stated that the buildings destroyed were mostly "not mosques" since they were "expansions of mosques in some private territories", and that some of the mosques destroyed were Sunni mosques. In September, twenty Bahraini medical professionals who had been arrested for treating protesters at the Salmaniya Medical Complex were handed jail terms of up to twenty years on charges of anti-government activity.Talea Miller, [https://www.pbs.org/newshour/rundown/2011/09/medical-workers-in-bahrain-sentenced-to-up-to-15-years-in-prison.html Medical Workers in Bahrain Sentenced to 15 Years in Prison], PBS NewsHour The international community immediately denounced the sentences, saying that they demonstrated a disregard for human rights and violated the principle of medical neutrality."Press Release, Physicians for Human Rights, (29 September 2011) [http://physiciansforhumanrights.org/press/press-releases/phr-denounces-sentences-on-bahraini-medics.html PHR Denounces Sentences Passed on Bahraini Medics and Protestors] In October, the Bahraini government nullified the convictions and scheduled retrials in civilian courts, which are ongoing.Rick Gladstone, New York Times, 5 October 2011 [https://www.nytimes.com/2011/10/06/world/middleeast/bahrain-orders-retrials-for-medical-workers.html?_r=2&hpw Bahrain Orders Retrials for Medical Workers] Despite promises of greater transparency, the Bahraini government has denied several human rights activists access to the trial, including Rick Sollom, Deputy Director of Physicians for Human Rights.Megan Prock, Physicians for Human Rights, 8 January 2011, [http://physiciansforhumanrights.org/press/press-releases/phr-condemns-bahraini-authorities-denial-of-entry-to-phr-deputy-director-on-eve-of-doctors-trial.html PHR Condemns Bahraini Authorities’ Denial of Entry to PHR Deputy Director on Eve of Doctors’ Trial] ===Controversies=== ====Mohamed Ramadan==== [[Hamad bin Isa Al Khalifa|Al Khalifa regime]] in [[Bahrain]], knowingly refused for more than two years to investigate complaints regarding the torture of [[Mohamed Ramadan (Victim)|Mohamed Ramadan]]—a father-of-three on [[death row]] who was [[tortured]] into making a false confession.{{cite web|title=Belfast to Bahrain: the torture trail|url=http://www.reprieve.org.uk/wp-content/uploads/2016/09/BelfastToBahrain.pdf|website=Reprieve}} In February 2014, Mohammed was arrested from Bahrain International Airport, where he worked as a police officer. He was accused of involvement in an attack on other police officers, despite a total [[Evidence|lack of evidence]] tying him to the crime. In reality, Mohammed is an innocent man who was arrested in [[retaliation]] for his attendance at [[Bahraini uprising (2011–present)|peaceful pro-democracy demonstrations]].{{cite web|title=Mohammed Ramadan|url=http://www.reprieve.org.uk/case-study/mohammed-ramadan/}} Following his arrest, Mohammed was [[Torture|brutally tortured]] by police into signing a '''false confession''', despite his innocence. During his initial detention, police officers ''told Mohammed outright that they knew he was innocent'', but were punishing him as a [[traitor]] for attending pro-democracy demonstrations. During his entire [[Detention (imprisonment)|detention]], Mohammed has never been allowed to meet with his lawyer. The day Mohammed's trial began was the first time he ever saw his lawyer's face. In that trial, he was convicted and [[sentenced to death]] almost solely on the basis of confessions extracted through prolonged torture. ====7 men under Capital punishment (2016)==== [[Reprieve (organisation)|Reprieve]] a [[human rights]] defender organisation published an investigative report about [[British government|Britain]] involvement in [[Bahraini uprising (2011–present)|Bahrain's]] regime atrocity in 2016. The report says that seven innocent men are facing the [[death penalty]] in Bahrain after being [[tortured]] into the false confessions of crimes.{{cite web|title=Britain Funded Torture Training in Bahrain|url=http://english.voiceofbahrain.org/?p=6744|website=Voice of Bahrain}} ====Sami Mushaima, Ali Al-Singace, Abbas Al-Samea (2017) Executed==== On 15 January 2017, [[Cabinet of Bahrain]] passed a [[capital punishment]] sentence of three Shia protesters convicted of orchestrating a bomb attack which killed 1 Emirati policeman from the [[Peninsula Shield Force]] and 2 Bahraini policemen on 3 March 2014. 42 year old [[Sami Mushaima]], 21 year old [[Ali Al-Singace]], and 27 year old [[Abbas Al-Samea]] confessed of orchestrating the bomb attack and were [[execution by firing squad|executed]] by firing squad.{{url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2017/01/15/bahraini-authorities-execute-three-shia-muslim-men-convicted/|publisher=Telegraph}} According to [[Americans for Democracy & Human Rights in Bahrain]], Bahrain security forces arrested Sami Mushaima in March 2014 and held him [[Solitary confinement|incommunicado]] for at least 11 days. Security officials subjected Mushaima to [[Strike (attack)|beatings]], [[electrocution]], [[sexual assault]], and severely damaged his front teeth. Mushaima's family believes he was [[coerced]] into falsely confessing through the use of torture. Sami Mushaima, Ali Al-Singace and Abbas Al-Samea executions have sparked protests from members of the opposition in Bahrain.{{cite news|title=Bahrain Executes Stateless Torture Victims Following King Hamad's Authorization|url=http://www.adhrb.org/2017/01/bahrain-executes-stateless-torture-victims-following-king-hamads-authorisation/|agency=Americans for Democracy & Human Rights in Bahrain}} ===Expulsions=== ''Al-wasat'' reported on 12 April, Issue no. 3139, that sixteen Lebanese nationals were requested by the Bahraini security services to leave the country. No details or reasons for the request were given.{{cite web|url = http://www.alwasatnews.com/3139/news/read/536876/1.html|script-title=ar:السلطات الأمنية تطلب من 16 لبنانياً مغادرة البحرين|language=Arabic|work=[[Alwasat (Bahraini newspaper)|Alwasat]]|accessdate=24 April 2011}} However, the Bahraini government claimed in a confidential report to the UN in April 2011 that Lebanese political organisation [[Hezbollah]], considered a terrorist group by the US, is present in Bahrain and is actively involved in the organisation of the unrest.Elise Labott [http://articles.cnn.com/2011-04-25/world/bahrain.hezbollah_1_wefaq-hezbollah-camps-hassan-nasrallah?_s=PM:WORLD "Bahrain government accuses Hezbollah of aiding opposition groups"]. CNN. 25 April 2011.Jay Solomon (25 April 2011). [https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB10001424052748703907004576279121469543918 "Bahrain Sees Hezbollah Plot in Protest"]. ''The Wall Street Journal''. In July 2014 Bahrain expelled the United States Assistant Secretary of State for Democracy, Human Rights and Labor, [[Tom Malinowski]], after he had met members of the leading [[Shia Islam|Shia]] opposition group, [[Al Wefaq|Al-Wefaq]], a move that the Foreign ministry of Bahrain said 'intervened in the country's domestic affairs'.{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-us-canada-28204511|title=US Diplomat Tom Malinowski Expelled from Bahrain|last=|first=|date=7 July 2014|work=BBC News|access-date=10 February 2018}} Previously, in May 2011, pro government websites and newspapers targeted US embassy's human rights officer, Ludovic Hood, and published information on where he and his family lived after accusing him of training and provoking demonstrations, being a Zionist and working in cooperation with Hezbollah.{{Cite news|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/indepth/features/2011/06/20116816139147194.html|title=The US and Bahrain. Sending Ludo home|last=Piven|first=Ben|date=10 July 2011|work=Al Jazeera|access-date=10 February 2018}} Hood had been photographed handing out donuts to demonstrators outside the US embassy in Bahrain. The US government subsequently withdrew Hood from Bahrain. ===Incarcerations=== Amongst the more prominent opposition figures, the Al-Khawaja family has been intermittently in and out of prison, even before the uprising began. Since the start of the uprising, Abdulhadi al-Khawaja, the former president of the Bahrain Centre for Human Rights, was placed on trial for his part in the uprising. On 22 June, he was sentenced to life in prison.{{cite news| url= https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/jun/22/bahrain-activist-zainab-al-khwaja | title= Bahraini activist's father jailed for life | author=Peter Walker | date= 22 June 2011|work=The Guardian |location=UK| accessdate=24 June 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110626232733/http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2011/jun/22/bahrain-activist-zainab-al-khwaja| archivedate= 26 June 2011 | deadurl= no}} His daughters and sons-in-law have also been intermittently in and out of prison since the counter-revolutionary crackdown by the government.{{cite news| url= http://thelede.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/06/22/bahrain-sentences-activists-to-life-in-jail/ | title= Bahrain Sentences Activists to Life in Jail | author=Robert Mackey | date= 22 June 2011|work=The Guardian |location=UK| accessdate=24 June 2011| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20110623185911/http://thelede.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/06/22/bahrain-sentences-activists-to-life-in-jail/| archivedate= 23 June 2011 | deadurl= no}} Ayat Al-Qurmezi was also found guilty of organising protests and assembling at the Pearl Roundabout and reading a poem critical of government policy. Sheikh Abdul-Aziz bin Mubarak, her spokesman, said that the poem "caused incitement and hatred to his majesty the king and to the prime minister" with lines such as "we are people who kill humiliation" and "assassinate misery."{{cite news| url= http://www.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/meast/06/12/bahrain.unrest/ | title= Bahrain tries ex-lawmakers, imprisons poet | author=[[Nic Robertson]] | date= 12 June 2011| publisher=CNN| accessdate=12 June 2011}} Human rights lawyer Mohammed al-Tajer was detained on 16 April 2011, apparently for providing legal support to other arrested activists.{{cite web|url=http://www.frontlinedefenders.org/node/14839 |title=Bahrain: Arrest and detention of human rights lawyer Mr Mohammed Al-Tajir |date=18 April 2011 |publisher=[[Front Line (NGO)|Front Line]] |accessdate=23 January 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120209233807/http://www.frontlinedefenders.org/node/14839 |archivedate=9 February 2012 |df=dmy }} He was held incommunicado for two months before being charged with inciting hatred for the regime, engaging in illegal protests, and inciting people to harm police.{{cite web |url=http://www.nycbar.org/44th-street-blog/2011/06/30/city-bar-calls-on-bahraini-government-to-respect-fundamental-rights-and-the-role-of-lawyers-cites-case-of-detained-defense-lawyer-mohammed-al-tajer/ |title=City Bar Calls on Bahraini Government to Respect Fundamental Rights and the Role of Lawyers; Cites Case of Detained Defense Lawyer Mohammed al-Tajer |date=30 June 2011 |work=44th Street Blog |publisher=[[New York City Bar Association]] |accessdate=23 January 2012}} He was released on 7 August, though the charges against him were not dropped.{{cite web |url=http://www.amnestyusa.org/actioncenter/actions/uaa11611.pdf |title=Lawyer released in Bahrain |date=9 August 2011 |publisher=[[Amnesty International]] |accessdate=23 January 2012}} As of 22 May, 515 detainees had been releasedMahmood Rafique [http://twentyfoursevennews.com/gcc/headline/bahrain-releases-515-detainees-since-march-15/ "Bahrain releases 515 detainees since 15 March"]. 24x7 News. 22 May 2011. and more than 140 were released on 9 August. ===Torture=== {{main|Torture during the Bahraini uprising (2011–present)}} Torture during the uprising has been described in many human rights reports as being widespread and systematic. 64%[http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2011/11/20111123125645404851.html Detainees number is 2,929] {{webarchive |url=https://www.webcitation.org/6B8lMge2D?url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2011/11/20111123125645404851.html |date=3 October 2012 }} of detainees (1,866 individuals) reported being tortured.{{cite report |title=Human Price of Freedom and Justice |publisher=[[Bahrain Centre for Human Rights]], [[Bahrain Youth Society for Human Rights]] and [[Bahrain Human Rights Society]] |url=http://bahrainrights.org/BCHR/wp-content/uploads/2011/11/BahrainTheHumanPrice.pdf |date=22 November 2011}}{{rp|37}} At least five individuals died as a result.{{rp|225}} During the uprising detainees were interrogated by three government agencies, the Ministry of Interior (MoI), the National Security Agency (NSA) and the [[Bahrain Defence Force]]. According to the Bahrain Independent Commission of Inquiry (BICI) report, physical and psychological abuse was inflicted by the NSA and the MoI on a systematic basis and in many cases amounted to torture.{{rp|298}} The BICI report describes the systematic use of techniques similar to those used during the repression of the 1990s uprising as indicative of "a systemic problem, which can only be addressed on a systemic level".{{rp|299–300}} ===Use of mercenaries=== For decades,[http://www.voanews.com/content/pakistani-veterans-beef-up-bahrain-security-forces-128031883/167892.html "Pakistani Veterans Beef Up Bahrain Security Forces"]. [[Voice of America]]. 17 August 2011. Retrieved 20 July 2012. the Bahraini authorities have been recruiting Sunni foreign nationals in the security forces from different countries, including Egypt,[https://www.hrw.org/node/88200/section/5 "Torture Redux"]. Human Rights Watch. 8 February 2010. Retrieved 21 July 2012. [[Jordan]], [[Syria]], Iraq ([[Ba'athism|Ba'athists]]), [[Yemen]] and [[Pakistan]] ([[Baloch people|Baluch]]) in order to confront any popular movement that usually comes from the Shia majority.[https://www.theguardian.com/world/2011/feb/17/bahrain-security-forces-sunni-foreign?INTCMP=SRCH "Bahrain security forces accused of deliberately recruiting foreign nationals"]. ''The Guardian''. 17 February 2011. Retrieved 20 July 2012. In 2009, Bahrain Centre for Human Rights claimed that 64 percent of National Security Agency employees were foreigners and that only 4 percent were Shia.{{cite web|url=http://www.bahrainrights.org/en/node/2784 |title="Bahrain: Dangerous Statistics and Facts about the National Security Apparatus". Bahrain Centre for Human Rights. 5 March 2009. Retrieved 20 July 2012 |publisher=Bahrainrights.org |date=8 March 2009}} Pakistanis mainly from [[Balochistan]] make up 30 percent of Bahrain security forces and are usually recruited via the [[Fauji Foundation]]. Bahrainis, ''Al Jazeera English'', ''[[Hindustan Times]]'',[http://www.hindustantimes.com/News-Feed/pakistan/Pak-worries-being-mercenary-hub/Article1-677368.aspx "Pak worries being mercenary hub"]. ''[[Hindustan Times]]''. 25 March 2011. Retrieved 20 July 2012. ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' magazine and [[Bruce Riedel]] referred to them as [[Mercenary|mercenaries]]. The Bahraini government admits it recruits foreigners in security forces, although it does not describe them as mercenaries. "We have no mercenaries. We have workers who have been serving at the Ministry of Interior for many years. Some of them have been naturalized and their children are working at the ministry", said [[Rashid bin Abdullah Al Khalifa]], the Minister of Interior.{{cite video |people=Sheikh Rashed bin Abdulla Al-Khalifa |date=19 October 2011 |script-title=ar:البحرين : مقابلة وزير الداخلية مع العربية |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=r3aPslQKl0Y#t=12m00s |medium=YouTube |language=Arabic |trans-title=Bahrain: an interview with the ministry of interior |publisher=Al-Arabiya (via Bahrain News Agency) |accessdate=20 July 2012 |time=12:00}} During the uprising, the deportation of Syrians and Pakistanis serving with the security forces was one of protesters' main goals; one of their slogans was against hiring Pakistanis in the riot police department. "There is no security when the police come from Pakistan", they chanted.{{cite video |date=4 August 2011 |title=Bahrain: Shouting in the dark |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xaTKDMYOBOU#t=15m50s |medium=YouTube|publisher=Al Jazeera|accessdate=20 July 2012 |time=15:50}} One month after the uprising began, the ministry of interior announced 20,000 jobs in security forces were available for Bahrainis, including protesters.[http://www.bahrainrights.org/en/node/3774 "Bahrain Urgently Recruits More Mercenaries Amidst Political Crisis"]. Bahrain Centre for Human Rights. 11 March 2011. Retrieved 20 July 2012. The move was considered a step to satisfy protesters' demands. However, advertisements of "urgent requirement" in the [[National Guard (Bahrain)|National Guard]], [[Special Security Force Command|special forces]] and riot police were spread in Pakistani media. The appearance of the advertisements was preceded by two "quiet trips" to Pakistan by [[Bandar bin Sultan]], now the Director General of the [[Al Mukhabarat Al A'amah|Saudi Intelligence Agency]]. Later, the Foreign Minister of Bahrain, [[Khalid bin Ahmed Al Khalifa]] and commander of the National Guard made a similar visit. It was only then that the advertisements started appearing.[http://www.aljazeera.com/indepth/features/2011/07/2011725145048574888.html "Pakistani troops aid Bahrain's crackdown"]. Al Jazeera. 30 July 2011. Retrieved 20 July 2012. The Pakistani government said they have "nothing to do" with these recruitments, because they are done via "private channels". However, the [[Islamic Republic News Agency|Iran News Agency]] reported that in August 2011, [[Asif Ali Zardari]], the President of Pakistan has agreed to send more Pakistani troops to Bahrain during his one-day visit to the country.[http://www.nation.com.pk/pakistan-news-newspaper-daily-english-online/Politics/22-Aug-2011/Pakistan-to-send-more-troops-to-Bahrain "Pakistan to send more troops to Bahrain"]. ''[[The Nation (Pakistani newspaper)|The Nation]]''. 22 August 2011. Retrieved 20 July 2012. It was also reported by ''[[The Jakarta Post]]'' that the Bahraini government tried to hire [[Malaysia]]n mercenaries.Dina Indrasafitri (22 June 2011). [http://www.thejakartapost.com/news/2011/06/22/govt-denies-hiring-out-mercenaries-bahrain.html "Govt denies hiring out mercenaries to Bahrain"]. ''[[The Jakarta Post]]''. Retrieved 20 July 2012. Al Jazeera English sources estimated that the number of riot police and the National Guard has increased by as high as 50 percent after at least 2,500 Pakistanis were recruited in April and May 2011. According to Nabeel Rajab, the exact size of the increase is not known, however he said it was "much more than 1,500 or 2,000". The size of the National Guard in 2011 was estimated by the US State Department to be 1,200. After requirements its size has increased by about 100 percent. Foreigner officers were among security forces ordered to attack protesters.Ishaan Tharoor (23 February 2011). [http://www.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,2053107,00.html "A History of Middle East Mercenaries"]. ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]''. Retrieved 20 July 2012. The BICI report mentioned that officers of Pakistani origins were responsible for mistreatment of detainees.[http://tribune.com.pk/story/297868/bahrain-commission-report-expats-subjected-to-physical-psychological-torture/ "Bahrain commission report: Expats subjected to ‘physical, psychological torture’"]. ''[[The Express Tribune]]''. 26 November 2011. Retrieved 20 July 2012. "He was beaten, tortured and hung. During the first three days, he was stripped of his clothes and sexually assaulted, in addition to being deprived of sleep ... He was routinely beaten and insulted by the prison guards, all of whom were of Pakistani origin", the report mentioned.{{rp|449}} Bahraini human rights groups and opposition parties have heavily criticized recruiting mercenaries in the Bahraini security forces. Nabeel Rajab said "They're told they are going to go to a [[Religious war|holy war]] in Bahrain to kill some non-Muslims or [[kafir]] [infidel] or Shias ... And those are maybe responsible for a lot of killing and a lot of systematic torture and human rights violations committed in the past months and years". Michael Stephens, of the [[Royal United Services Institute]] linked recruiting mercenaries in the Bahraini security forces to the lack of government confidence in its own citizens. "So they rely on foreign recruits to unquestioningly carry out orders of violently suppressing protests", he said. Bruce Riedel, a leading American expert on South Asia said "when the very serious demonstrations began and it looked like the regime might even be toppled at a certain point, their hiring of mercenaries went up substantially". ==Casualties== [[File:Bahrain uprising graffiti in Barbar (6).JPG|thumb|A graffiti depicting eight victims labelled as "[[martyr]]s"]] {{Main|Casualties of the Bahraini uprising of 2011 and its aftermath}} As of 2014, the uprising had resulted in about 164 deaths.{{cite web|title=164 Protesters Killed in Bahrain since Start of Uprising: Opposition|url=http://www.tasnimnews.com/English/Home/Single/373903|publisher=Tasnim News Agency|accessdate=2014-05-29}} The number of injuries is hard to determine due to government clamp-down on hospitals and medical personnel. The last accurate estimate for injuries is from 16 March 2011 and sits at about 2,708. The Bahrain Independent Commission of Inquiry concluded that many detainees were subjected to torture and other forms of physical and psychological abuse while in police custody, leading to the death of five detainees. The BICI report finds the government responsible for 20 deaths (November 2011). Opposition activists say that the current number is about 78 including 34 who allegedly died as a result of excessive use of tear gas. ===Injuries=== The total number of injured since the start of the uprising is not known. This is due to protesters fear of being arrested while receiving treatment at hospitals for injuries sustained during the protest.{{cite news|title=Bahrain: MSF Condemns Armed Raid On Office and Detention of Staff Member |date=3 August 2011 |publisher=[[Médecins Sans Frontières]] |url=http://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/press/release.cfm?id=5484&cat=press-release |accessdate=10 March 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111008175432/http://www.doctorswithoutborders.org/press/release.cfm?id=5484&cat=press-release |archivedate=8 October 2011 }} As of 16 March 2011, the total number is, at least 2,708.4 on 14 February (BICI page 68), 25 on 15 February [http://www.aljazeera.com/news/middleeast/2011/02/201121571645551445.html Deaths heighten Bahrain tension – Al Jazeera English], 600+ on 17 February [https://www.nytimes.com/2011/02/18/opinion/18kristof.html?_r=2 Blood Runs Through the Streets of Bahrain – NYTimes.com], 774 on 11 March [http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/meast/03/11/bahrain.clashes/index.html?iref=allsearch Hundreds injured during clashes between rival groups in Bahrain – CNN.com], 905+ on 13 March [http://www.alwasatnews.com/3111/news/read/532288/1.html] [http://www.alwasatnews.com/3110/news/read/532142/1.html] [http://www.alwasatnews.com/3110/news/read/532149/1.html], 250 on 15 March [http://www.alwasatnews.com/3113/news/read/532534/1.html] and 150+ on 16 March [http://edition.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/meast/03/16/bahrain.protests/index.html?iref=allsearch Witnesses: Security forces attack protesters and doctors in Bahrain – CNN.com] Another 200 injuries were treated by Médecins Sans Frontières outside hospitals, for a total of 2,908. A doctor who asked to remain anonymous said he secretly treats about 50 injured protesters a week (~2,500 in a year).{{cite news | author=Bill Law | title = Bahrain's 'underground medics' secretly treat injured protesters | date=24 February 2012 | publisher=BBC | url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-17141305 | accessdate=18 March 2012}} In addition, minister of Interior Rashid bin Abdullah Al Khalifa claimed that 395 police officers were injured, four of them allegedly "abducted and tortured".[http://www.arabianbusiness.com/bahrain-minister-says-24-people-dead-in-uprisings-390813.html Bahrain minister says 24 people dead in uprisings]. ArabianBusiness.com. 29 March 2011. Retrieved 9 April 2011. ===Deaths=== [[File:Sayed Hashim body at the bather.jpg|thumb|The government claims that the burns on Sayed Hashim's body were inconsistent with burns caused by a tear gas canister]] [[File:Abdulredha Buhmaid on floor.jpeg|thumb|Bahraini protesters shot by military, February 18, 2011]] [[File:Remains of US made tear gas canicters in Bahrain.JPG|thumb|In front an empty US-made tear gas canister]] The Bahrain Independent Commission of Inquiry found that there were 35 deaths between 14 February and 15 April 2011 linked to the uprising. The Commission found the government responsible for 20 of these deaths, protesters responsible for 3, and mobs responsible for 2. The Commission could not attribute the remaining 10 deaths to a perpetrator. Additionally, the Commission found that there were another 11 deaths potentially linked to the uprising between 16 April and 6 October 2011. Between 7 October 2011 and 5 April 2012, the Bahrain Centre for Human Rights (BCHR) reported 32 deaths linked to the uprising, for a total of 78 deaths. The total number, counting all related incidents, even those not mentioned in the BICI report and BCHR is 90 deaths as of 21 April 2012. Bahrain's ''Gulf Daily News'' newspaper reported that anti-government protesters attacked and killed an elderly taxi driver on 13 March.{{cite news|url=http://m.gulf-daily-news.com/NewsDetails.aspx?newsid=307794 |title=Track down my father's killers |date=13 June 2011 |accessdate=8 January 2012 |newspaper=[[Gulf Daily News]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120120040640/http://m.gulf-daily-news.com/NewsDetails.aspx?newsid=307794 |archivedate=20 January 2012 |df=dmy }} Other local newspapers reported that he was beaten to death by "terrorists."{{cite news|url=http://www.dt.bh/newsdetails.php?key=301110213450&newsid=230411234508 |archive-url=https://archive.is/20120724180707/http://www.dt.bh/newsdetails.php?key=301110213450&newsid=230411234508 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=24 July 2012 |title=Martyrs' Families Visited |date=24 April 2011 |accessdate=8 January 2012 |newspaper=Daily Tribune }}{{cite news|url=http://www.alayam.com/Articles.aspx?aid=73184 |title=طعنه الإرهابيون بوحشية وبلا رأفة وسكاكينهم اخترقت جسده النحيل |date=28 March 2011 |accessdate=8 December 2012 |newspaper=[[Al Ayam (Bahrain)|Al Ayam]] |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120119062925/http://www.alayam.com/Articles.aspx?aid=73184 |archivedate=19 January 2012 }} Bahrain's independent Al-Wasat newspaper cited witnesses saying the taxi driver died in a traffic accident.{{cite news |url=http://www.alwasatnews.com/3120/news/read/533682/1.html |title=تشييع جنازة راشد المعمري بمقبرة الرفاع |newspaper=[[Al-Wasat (Bahraini newspaper)|Al-Wasat]] |date=22 March 2011 |accessdate=8 January 2012}} The Bahrain Independent Commission of Inquiry did not report any such death connected to the unrest.
